_header: Black be thy bands and thy weed also
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1988)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse Printed 1476-1558. London: Mansell, 1988, TP 253.5
_description: Envoy attached to end of two long verse works — one or four rhyme royal stanzas

BodArcSelB24.First Lines:
Blak be thy bandis and thy wede alsoThou soroufull book of mater
                    disesparit…
BodArcSelB24.Last Lines:
…That hast within so many a soroufull clauseSuich be thyne
                    habyte as thou hast thy cause
BodArcSelB24.Note: One stanza only at end of Troilus and Criseyde, 5248.
BodArcSelB24.Editions:
Brown,  John Thomas Toshach. 
             The Authorship of the Kingis Quair.
         Glasgow, New York, London: Macmillan, 1896: 72.
Root,  Robert Kilburn. 
             The Mansucripts of Chaucer’s Troilus….
Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 98. London: Trübner, 1914: 43.

RylandsEng2.First Lines:
Blake be thy bondes and thy wede alsooThou sorowfull book of matier
                    disespeiredIn tokne of thyn inward mortal wooWhiche is so badde it may
                    not be enpeired…
RylandsEng2.Last Lines:
…That him translated in Englissh of latyneTherfore now take
                    him for a man of thyne
RylandsEng2.Note: Four stanzas at end of Lydgate’s Fall of Princes, 1904.
RylandsEng2.Attributed Title: Greneacres a lenvoye vpon John Bochas (f. 184ra)
RylandsEng2.Editions:
Bergen,  Henry,
                        ed.  
             Lydgate’s Fall of Princes.
             4 vols. 
             EETS
         e.s. 121-24 (1924-27); repr. 1967: 1023.

PULTayM2.First Lines:
Blake be thy bondis and In wede alsoThow sorofull booke of mater
                    dissespeyredIn tokene of thyne Inwarde mortall woo…
PULTayM2.Last Lines:
…yit was it makid of þi monkys booteThat hym translate in
                    Englisch of latyne
